citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two mountain coati were observed excessively itching with patchy hair loss. Upon closer inspection, black insects were
observed within the hair coat. The presence of insects were pointed out to the licensee and he informed us that the
animals are due to receive treatment/prevention for external parasites next week. The condition had not been identified by
the facility prior to the inspection and as a result, the condition of these animals were not communicated to the Attending
Veterinarian and they did not receive veterinary care. Daily observations of animals to identify medical problems is
essential to identify conditions quickly and initiate treatment within a timely manor. Correct by observing all animals at
least daily to identify physical, medical, or behavioral problems. Additionally, ensure that all findings are communicated in
a timely manner to the Attending Veterinarian so that they can examine animals and ensure that appropriate treatment is
provided as required by section 2.40(b)(3). Correct by 5/13/2025.

There was a large accumulation of old farm equipment, new and old fencing material, scrap metal and additional
miscellaneous items in the pasture that contained 22 fallow deer. These materials can cause injury to the animals if they
become trapped in the equipment or run into sharp edges. Premises shall be kept clean and in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash
and equipment shall be placed in designated areas outside of animal enclosures and cleared as necessary to protect the
health of the animals. Correct by 5/20/2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Multiple areas in and around the enclosures that house birds need a more robust pest control program.
- In and around the enclosures that housed 125 chickens contained an abundance of flies.
- In the walk-through aviary, the smell of rodent urine was noted and approximately 50% of the dirt floor contained
burrowing holes that indicated the potential for rodent activity. Upon closer inspection, 3 dead decomposed rodents were
located in cobweb covered live traps.
Pests such as flies and rodents can affect the health and well-being of animals by spreading disease and contaminating
food, surfaces, and animal housing areas. Correct by 5/20/2025 by establishing and maintaining an effective program to
control insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests to promote the health and well-being of the animals and
reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
COURTNEY JERNIGAN, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Two mountain coati were observed excessively itching with patchy hair loss. Upon closer inspection, black insects were 
observed within the hair coat. The presence of insects were pointed out to the licensee and he informed us that the 
animals are due to receive treatment/prevention for external parasites next week. The condition had not been identified by 
the facility prior to the inspection and as a result, the condition of these animals were not communicated to the Attending 
Veterinarian and they did not receive veterinary care. Daily observations of animals to identify medical problems is 
essential to identify conditions quickly and initiate treatment within a timely manor. Correct by observing all animals at 
least daily to identify physical, medical, or behavioral problems. Additionally, ensure that all findings are communicated in 
a timely manner to the Attending Veterinarian so that they can examine animals and ensure that appropriate treatment is 
provided as required by section 2.40(b)(3). Correct by 5/13/2025. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
There was a large accumulation of old farm equipment, new and old fencing material, scrap metal and additional 
miscellaneous items in the pasture that contained 22 fallow deer. These materials can cause injury to the animals if they 
become trapped in the equipment or run into sharp edges. Premises shall be kept clean and in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash 
and equipment shall be placed in designated areas outside of animal enclosures and cleared as necessary to protect the 
health of the animals. Correct by 5/20/2025. 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Multiple areas in and around the enclosures that house birds need a more robust pest control program.  
- In and around the enclosures that housed 125 chickens contained an abundance of flies.  
- In the walk-through aviary, the smell of rodent urine was noted and approximately 50% of the dirt floor contained 
burrowing holes that indicated the potential for rodent activity. Upon closer inspection, 3 dead decomposed rodents were 
located in cobweb covered live traps.  
Pests such as flies and rodents can affect the health and well-being of animals by spreading disease and contaminating 
food, surfaces, and animal housing areas. Correct by 5/20/2025 by establishing and maintaining an effective program to

control insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests to promote the health and well-being of the animals and 
reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
COURTNEY JERNIGAN, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
